instruction: Describe the theoretical and algorithmic contributions of the authors in this paper.
output: The authors' theoretical and algorithmic contributions focus on recent advancements in statistical literature regarding robust estimation. They discuss the work of Lugosi and Mendelson (2019b), who constructed a multivariate mean estimator based on the median-of-means idea originally proposed by Nemirovsky and Yudin (1983). This estimator has favorable properties, such as high probability deviation bounds with minimal loss in accuracy, and only requires that the second moment of each component of the random vector is bounded. However, the original estimator was not computationally tractable. The authors then discuss the work of Hopkins (2020), who proposed an estimator with polynomial computational complexity, and subsequent research by Depersin and Lecué (2022) and Hopkins et al. (2020) that led to nearly linear-time algorithms. The authors also mention the work of Mendelson and Zhivotovskiy (2020), who proposed an abstract algorithm for covariance estimation that achieves performance similar to the Gaussian sample covariance estimator under four bounded moments assumptions. The authors note that it remains an open question whether such performance can be achieved with a polynomial algorithm.
